A series of Cu-based catalysts with different types of supports (TiO2, Al2O3, S-1, HZSM-5 SiO2/Al2O3 =27 and 85) were investigated for selective catalytic combustion of acetonitrile (CH3CN). Among all catalysts, the Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts had superior activity accompanied with the generation of massive NO x , while Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts exhibited excellent N2 selectivity. The characterization results indicated that the surface acidity of catalysts played a decisive role in reaction behavior. For the Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts mainly with Lewis acid sites, CH3CN underwent an initial hydrolysis step with surface hydroxy group to form acetamide anion (CH3CONHad), then occurred further hydrolysis reaction to form NH3 at low temperatures, or turned to proceed oxidation reaction with numerous NO x generation at high temperatures. Whereas, the enriched Brønsted acid sites on the Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts brought abundant isolated Cu2+ ions, which guaranteed the processing of iSCR reaction, thereby promoting the occurrence of hydrolysis and oxidation reaction pathways in parallel and benefiting the improvement of N2 selectivity. These results elucidated the influence of supports with different acidic types in reaction pathway and provided precious reference for the development of high-performance NVOCs catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Acetonitrile Selective catalytic combustion Cu-based catalysts Acid types Reaction mechanism Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Acetonitrile (CH3CN), as an indispensable solvent, is extensively applied in chemical production processes [1,2]. However, CH3CN existed in nitrile waste gas from factories has serious toxicity and harmfulness [3]. And one of the most promising technologies for purifying nitrile waste gas is selective catalytic combustion (SCC) [2,4–10]. As the key challenge to the practical application of SCC technology, the development of high-performance catalysts with high activity and N2 selectivity has great practical significance. Nowadays, the catalysts applied for nitrile waste gas catalytic combustion include supported noble metals and transition metal oxides [2,4–9,11,12]. The supported noble metal catalysts (Pd, Pt) showed excellent catalytic activity, but their N2 selectivity was not satisfactory [7,8,12,13]. In comparison, among the supported transition metal oxide catalysts, Cu-based catalysts represented positive potential in industrial applications due to their excellent N2 selectivity within relative wider temperature window [14]. As reported, Zhang et. al [15] found that Cu/SBA-15 catalyst exhibited around 80 % N2 selectivity at T > 350 °C. And further mechanism research by DRIFTS concluded that CH3CN degradation to N2 on Cu/SBA-15 catalyst mainly followed oxidation pathway reaction via isocyanide (NCO) intermediate. Additionally, in our previous study of mechanism research on CH3CN-SCC process over Cu/ZSM-5 catalyst [5], both oxidation and hydrolysis pathways of CH3CN were observed and internal selective catalytic reduction (iSCR) process between NO x (oxidation product) and NH3 (hydrolysis product) guaranteed the excellent N2 selectivity. Apart from the active component, the support also plays a greatly important role in the catalytic activity of nitriles. As Nanba et al. [9] reported, Ag/TiO2 and Ag/SiO2 catalysts exhibited higher N2 selectivity (>80 % at 350 °C) than Ag catalysts supported on other supports (ZSM-5, Al2O3, MgO, and ZrO2) because the coexistence of oxidized and metallic Ag on Ag/TiO2 and Ag/SiO2 catalysts promoted C2H3CN degradation. Nanba et al. [16] further found Cu catalysts supported on metal oxidizes (Al2O3, TiO2, SiO2, MgO, and ZrO2) showed much worse N2 selectivity than the case of Cu/ZSM-5 catalyst during the C2H3CN-SCC process, which may be closely related with Cu ions. Zhang et al. [17] had investigated the acrylonitrile SCC reaction performances over different Cu-zeolite catalysts. They concluded that more Cu2+ ions at low SiO2/Al2O3 were beneficial to improve the activity and N2 selectivity. In these literatures [8,11,16–18], most works paid attention to the effect of supports on chemical states of active component as well as SCC performances. In this work, it was obtained the reaction pathway was actually also related to the types of supports. Therefore, although significant progress has been made in terms of screening supports for Cu-based catalysts to improve catalytic performance, the impact of different supports on the reaction mechanism still needs to be further clarified. Therefore, this study focused on the difference of CH3CN-SCC reaction behaviors caused by different acid supports over Cu-based catalysts. Specifically, TiO2 and Al2O3 were selected as the typical supports mainly with Lewis acid sites, and HZSM-5 with different SiO2/Al2O3 ratios (27 and 85) were chose as supports with abundant Brønsted acid sites. And S-1 zeolite without acidity basically was selected for comparison. Then, the physicochemical properties of the catalysts were characterized by various structural and surface property measurements. After that, in-situ DRIFTS was carried out to investigate CH3CN decomposition mechanisms over various Cu-based catalysts with different acidity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The reagents used in this study were analytical grade. Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and Al2O3 were purchased from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. P25 was purchased from Degussa Co., Ltd. HZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 =27), HZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 =85) and S-1 zeolite were purchased from Tianjin Zeolite Plant of Nankai University. The Cu-based catalysts with different supports (TiO2, Al2O3, HZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 =27), HZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 =85), S-1) were synthesized via wet impregnation method. Specifically, 0.755 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was dissolved into deionized water (40 mL). Then, 4 g of support powder was added to the solution to load with Cu species (5 wt %). After stirring at room temperature (r.t.) for 6 h, the suspension was dried at 120 °C for 12 h. Then the powder was placed in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 4 h. Finally, the sample were sieved into 40–60 meshes to be prepared. The obtained catalysts were denoted as Cu/TiO2, Cu/Al2O3, Cu/ZSM-5(27), Cu/ZSM-5(85) and Cu/S-1, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The structural and morphological properties of catalysts were characterized by transmission electron microscope (TEM), X-ray diffractometer (XRD) and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET). The surface chemical states, acidity and reducibility of catalysts were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), infrared spectroscopic of adsorbed pyridine (Py-IR) and H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), respectively. The reaction mechanism of various catalysts was mainly elucidated by in-situ infrared spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS). The detailed information was given in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic performance of the catalysts was evaluated in a continuous flow fixed-bed quartz microreactor. The detailed procedures of catalytic performance evaluation were provided in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity of the catalysts Fig. 1 and Fig. S1 showed the catalytic performance for CH3CN degradation over Cu-based catalysts with different supports. As shown in Fig. 1a, Cu/TiO2 catalyst exhibited the highest CH3CN conversion with T90 = 275 °C, which followed by Cu/Al2O3 (T90 =324 °C), Cu/ZSM-5(27) (T90 =338 °C), Cu/ZSM-5(85) (T90 =361 °C) and Cu/S-1 (T90 =392 °C) catalysts. The CO2 yield (Fig. 1b) displayed the same sequence as CH3CN conversion. And the release of CO during 250–400 °C (Fig. S1a) manifested the incomplete oxidation of CH3CN occurred at low temperature. To evaluate the N2 selectivity of various catalysts, the yield of NH3, NO x , N2O and N2 selectivity was depicted in Fig. 1c, d and Fig. S1b, c, respectively. From Fig. 1c, it could be found that the NH3 yield exhibited a volcano shape with temperature increasing and the highest NH3 yield was obtained to be 32 % at 275 °C for Cu/TiO2 catalyst. It was worth noting that Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited significantly higher NH3 yield than Cu-based zeolite catalysts. And the temperature of NH3 yield on Cu/Al2O3 catalyst was much higher than that of Cu/TiO2 catalyst, which could be associated with their different hydrolysis capacities of supports. These results fitted well with that founded in the previous literature that TiO2 was of better nitriles hydrolysis activity than Al2O3, where both supports were superior to H-ZSM-5 [19]. Moreover, among zeolite samples, the NH3 yield of Cu/ZSM-5(85) catalyst was higher than that of Cu/ZSM-5(27), while Cu/S-1 catalyst exhibited the lowest NH3 yield (9.6 % at 350 °C). Additionally, the generation of NO x and N2O could be observed above 300 °C (Fig. 1d and Fig. S1b), indicating that nitrogen-containing intermediates could be further oxidized to N2O or NO x with the temperature rising. The yield of NO x (Fig. 1d) followed the sequence: Cu/TiO2 > Cu/S-1 > Cu/Al2O3 > Cu/ZSM-5(85) > Cu/ZSM-5(27), and Cu/TiO2 catalyst had the highest NO x yield (32.8 %) at 400 °C. As for N2O (Fig. S1b), the maximum yield was obtained for Cu/Al2O3 catalyst (14.3 % at 450 °C). In general, Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts exhibited better N2 selectivity (above 90 %) than other catalysts (Fig. S1c). The CH3CN-TPSR results (Fig. S2) further confirmed the observation in activity tests that temperatures required of Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 conversion were lower than other samples and they also showed more abundant NH3 release among the catalysts investigated. And Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 samples exhibited more NO emission and less N2 formation compared to ZSM-5 based samples. The activity test results of these investigated catalysts were consistent with those reported in the previous literatures (see Table S1) [16,17]. To sum up, Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts had higher CH3CN conversion with large amounts of N2O or NO x generation. In comparison, Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts possessed better N2 selectivity, and Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst exhibited higher than 95 % N2 selectivity from 350° to 500°C. And Cu/S-1 catalyst showed the lowest CH3CN conversion with NO (17 % at T = 400 °C) being of the main N-containing byproduct except for N2. By comparing Cu/ZSM-5(27) with Cu/ZSM-5(85) catalysts, it can be further found that lower SiO2/Al2O3 ratio was much more conducive to reduce undesirable N-containing byproduct yield of Cu/ZSM-5. The differences in the generation amount of the byproducts (NH3, N2O and NO x ) over investigated catalysts manifested that various reaction mechanisms occurring over these Cu-based catalysts with different supports. As such, the following characterizations and DRIFTS study were performed to further clear out their different reaction behaviors. 3.2 Structural and morphological properties The XRD profiles of different catalysts were displayed in Fig. 2. The typical peaks attributed to the anatase and rutile binary TiO2 phases (JCPDS No. 21–1272 and 21–1276), γ-Al2O3 phase (JCPDS No.47–1308) and ZSM-5 phases (JCPDS No. 44–0003) could be observed in the XRD patterns of the corresponding Cu-based catalysts [5,20,21]. Furthermore, the diffraction peak assigned to the CuO crystalline phase (JCPDS No. 895899) centered at 35.6° and 38.8° appeared obviously on all the catalysts with different supports [22], demonstrating the existence of CuO on the catalysts. The specific surface areas, pore volumes and pore diameter of catalysts were presented in Table 1 and Figs. S3, 4. The zeolite catalysts showed much higher specific surface areas than Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 3 exhibited the morphology of the investigated catalysts by TEM, HR-TEM, HAADF-TEM and EDS mapping. It could be observed from HRTEM results that CuO particles existed in all Cu-based catalysts, which showed the crystal faces (111) with the interplanar spacing of 0.259 nm. This result was fitted well with the XRD characterization. In addition, the Cu dispersion in Cu/TiO2 was found better than other samples, which was possibly due to the strong interaction between CuO with TiO2 support [23]. 3.3 Surface chemical states, acidity and reducibility analysis XPS measurement was conducted to investigate the surface chemical states of the catalysts. And the relative atomic ratios of the catalysts were calculated and presented in Fig. 4. The full-scan XPS result (Fig. S5) manifested the existence of Cu elements on all the catalysts. High-resolution Cu 2p spectra ( Fig. 4a) was deconvoluted into three groups peaks. The peaks at 935.8 and 957.0 eV were due to Cu2+ ions, the peaks at 933.5–934.7 and 953.0–954.6 eV were assigned to CuO species, the peaks at 932.5–932.8 and 952.0–952.5 eV were attributed to Cu(I) species in Cu2O [24–28]. And the shake-up satellite peak between 940.0 and 947.0 eV verified the existence of CuO species, which was accordance with the XRD and TEM results above. The O 1 s spectrum (Fig. 4b) could be deconvoluted into three peaks assigned to surface lattice oxygen species (Oα, at 529.8–530.8 eV), adsorbed active oxygen species (Oβ, at 531.5–531.8 eV) and hydroxyl species and adsorbed water species (Oγ, at 532.4–533.2 eV) [29,30]. It could be found that Cu2+ ions existed on all Cu-based zeolite catalysts while no obvious XPS signals of Cu2+ ions could be detected on Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts. As noted, Cu2+ ions were the active site to generate N2 [8], so the lack of surface Cu2+ ions species could be one of the important reasons for the poor N2 selectivity of Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts. Additionally, it can be observed that the proportion of Cu2+ ions on Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst (59 %) was much higher than that of Cu/ZSM-5(85) catalyst (28.68 %), which was due to that the lower ratio of SiO2/Al2O3 was more conducive to Cu2+ ions generation via ion exchanges [17]. This was the key reason that lower SiO2/Al2O3 ratio was much more favorable for improving N2 yield of Cu/ZSM-5 catalyst. For oxygen species of catalysts, the value of Oβ/Ototal (adsorbed active oxygen species/total oxygen species) decreased in the order of Cu/Al2O3 > Cu/TiO2 > Cu/ZSM-5(27) > Cu/ZSM-5(85) > Cu/S-1. As is well known [31,32], chemisorbed oxygen species in catalysts favored the catalytic oxidation performance. In light of this, it could be found that the sequence of Oβ/Ototal was basically accordance with the sequence of CH3CN conversion and CO2 yield except Cu/Al2O3 and Cu/TiO2 catalysts. This could be correlated with superior reducibility of Cu/TiO2 catalyst, which would be discussed next. H2-TPR measurements were performed to investigate the reducibility of the prepared catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5a, Cu/TiO2 catalyst showed three main peaks at 173 °C, 191 °C and 263 °C, which were attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO x species interacted with the TiO2 support, larger CuO clusters and CuO bulk, respectively [33,34]. For Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst, the reduction peaks at 218 °C, 236 °C and 263 °C were assigned to the reduction of isolated Cu2+ ions, highly dispersed CuO x species and CuO bulk, respectively [35–38]. And Cu/Al2O3 catalyst showed two main peaks at 219 °C and 249 °C, respectively. The first reduction peak was attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO x species and the latter peak was belonged to the reduction of larger CuO clusters or particles [39,40]. On Cu/ZSM-5(85) catalyst, two reduction peaks assigned to isolated Cu2+ ions/fine CuO x particles (at around 252 °C) and large CuO bulks (at 281 °C) could be observed. Most notably, only one sharp H2 reduction peak attributed to large CuO particles could be observed at 288 °C for Cu/S-1 sample [41], manifesting poor interactions between Cu species and S-1 support. These results were in good accordance with the XPS results above. Additionally, the lower reduction temperature of CuO x species for TiO2/Al2O3 supported samples especially Cu/TiO2 catalyst could be attributed to the improved dispersion due to strong interactions between CuO x species and supports [23,39]. According to the reduction temperature of H2 reduction, it was clear that the reducibility of catalysts followed the order as: Cu/TiO2 > Cu/Al2O3 > Cu/ZSM-5(27) > Cu/ZSM-5(85) > Cu/S-1, which was corresponded to the trend of CH3CN conversion and CO2 yield. NH3-TPD and Py-IR tests were conducted to reveal the acidity property of the prepared catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5b, the NH3 desorption peaks at 100–250 °C, 250–400 °C, and 400–600 °C were attributed to the weak, moderate and strong acid sites of the catalysts, respectively [29,42]. The total acidity of the catalysts exhibited the following order: Cu/ZSM-5(27) > Cu/ZSM-5(85) > Cu/TiO2 > Cu/Al2O3 > Cu/S-1. And the IR spectra at different temperatures for the catalysts after pyridine adsorption was displayed in Fig. 5c, d and the concentration of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites from Py-IR spectra was provided in Table 2. The assignments of the bands could be attributed to the pyridine adsorption on various sites as follows: 1636 and 1545 cm−1, Brønsted acid sites; 1612, 1453, and 1445 cm−1, Lewis acidic site; 1490 cm−1, both Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites [20,43]. It could be seen from Table 2 that the ratio of Brønsted acid content to Lewis acid content (B/L) decreased following the sequence: Cu/ZSM-5(27) > Cu/ZSM-5(85) > Cu/Al2O3 > Cu/TiO2. Furthermore, Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst exhibited the highest Brønsted acidity (174.90 μmol/g at 350 °C) while Cu/S-1 catalyst owned the lowest total acidity (9.26 μmol/g at 350 °C). These results indicated that Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst had the strongest Brønsted acid centers, while Cu/TiO2 catalyst owned the strongest Lewis acid sites. The different features of various samples in acidity could be the reasons of their diverse NH3 yield during CH3CN catalytic conversion. As the first step of nitriles hydrolysis, the water activation was supposed to be easier over TiO2/Al2O3 with mainly Lewis acidity compared to H-ZSM-5 with strong Brønsted acidity [44–46]. As for Cu/S-1 sample, its less acidity nature damped the water activation, resulting in the little activity in hydrolysis to form NH3. 3.4 Reaction mechanism investigation In-situ DRIFTS characterization in this section was employed to investigate the CH3CN SCC mechanism over various samples under different temperatures. And the assignment of IR peaks over the catalysts was listed in Table S2. Fig. 6a-c depicted DRIFTS spectra of CH3CN oxidation over Cu/ZSM-5(27), Cu/ZSM-5(85) and Cu/S-1 catalysts, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6a, the peaks at 2293, 2261, 2322, 2933 and 2999 cm−1 could be observed, which were attributed to δCH3 + ν(C–C), ν(CN), νs(CH3) and νa(CH3), respectively [15,47–49]. These bands were associated with the adsorbed CH3CN molecule on the catalyst. At 150 °C, the bands assigned to acetamide (CH3CONH2) (at 1664 and 1585 cm−1) and NH x species (at 3363, 3276, 3178 cm−1) appeared, which were originated from the hydrolysis of CH3CN [50]. With the temperature increased to 200 °C, the peaks belonged to CH3CONH2 and NH x species gradually became more intense. Meanwhile, the new band at 2170 cm−1 could be observed clearly, which was related to CO species, which was derived from the incomplete oxidation of carbon-containing intermediates. As the temperature further rising to 250 °C, the band assigned to CH3COOH appeared at 1695 cm−1, which could be generated from the hydrolysis of acetamide (CH3CONH2) [2]. At 300 °C, the new band at 2208 cm−1 belonged to NCO species could be observed. The appearance of NCO species confirmed the occurrence of CH3CN oxidation reaction pathways. [13]. It was worth noting that the peak intensity of both hydrolysis intermediate (NH x species) and oxidation intermediate (NCO species) increased simultaneously from 300 °C to 350 °C, indicating that these pathways proceeded concurrently during the CH3CN degradation over Cu/ZSM–5(27) catalyst, which was accordance with our previous results [5,51]. As is well known [51], the intermediate products (NH x and NO x ) of hydrolysis and oxidation would proceed iSCR process to generate N2 on the Cu2+ sites. As such, Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst exhibited excellent N2 selectivity. Compared to Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst, there was no significant difference on the intermediate species of in-situ DRIFTS on Cu/ZSM-5(85) catalyst (Fig. 6b) except for the new broad band at 2500–3500 cm−1 at low temperature. This broad band was associated with the strong hydrogen bonding between CH3CN and Si-OH on the catalyst [52,53]. Moreover, it could be found that the intensity of this broad band decreased with the temperature rising, which was unsurprising because the weaker interaction between CH3CN and Si-OH at higher temperature. Additionally, although both oxidation and hydrolysis reaction pathways of CH3CN occurred simultaneously, there were remarkable differences in the intensity of intermediate products. As shown in Fig. 6b, at 350 °C, the peak intensity for CH3CN adsorption at 2322 and 2293 cm−1 on Cu/ZSM-5(85) catalyst was more intense than that for Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst. This demonstrated that the CH3CN conversion on Cu/ZSM-5(85) catalyst was much slower, which was understandable given its worse reducibility than Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst. It was worth noting that the peak intensity of oxidation characteristic product (NCO species) increased gradually as the temperature increasing from 200° to 350°C. But the peak of hydrolysis characteristic products (CH3CONH2 and NH x ) did not change basically, indicating the weaker hydrolysis pathway occurred than oxidation pathway on Cu/ZSM-5(85) catalyst. These results verified the activity that more NO x release over Cu/ZSM-5(85) catalyst compared to Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst. In addition, it could be found that the IR band (at 2170 cm–1) assigned to CO on Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst was much more intense than that on Cu/ZSM-5(85) catalyst. This could be related to the faster CH3CN conversion and the enhanced adsorption of CO on stronger acidic sites of Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst [54]. For the in-situ DRIFTS of Cu/S-1 catalyst (Fig. 6c), more intense band at 2500–3500 cm−1 could be observed at low temperature compared to Cu/ZSM-5(85) catalyst, which was related to the more abundant Si-OH on the Cu/S-1 catalyst. Additionally, it could also be found that CH3CONH2 species appeared at 150 °C. But unlike Cu/ZSM-5(27/85), the band assigned to CH3COOH species (at 1695 cm−1) cannot be observed during the entire temperature range. This demonstrated that the generation of NH3 and CH3COOH from further hydrolysis process of CH3CONH2 species was not able to occur completely. Based on the activity tests and the DRIFTS results above, the hydrolysis reaction was barely happened on Cu/S-1 sample, where the less acidity could be the main reason. The band attributed to NCO species (2208 cm−1) became apparent until the temperature rising to 300 °C, manifesting the oxidation pathway of CH3CN was proceeded at high temperature though the activity was lower than other ZSM-5 catalysts. Combined with the release of massive NO x in activity test results (Fig. 1d), it was deduced that the process of CH3CN degradation over Cu/S-1 catalyst mainly followed the oxidation mechanism. In comparison, the in-situ IR spectra of CH3CN oxidation over Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts were apparently different ( Fig. 7a, b). At 100 °C, the bands attributed to adsorbed CH3CN molecule (at 2261, 2293 and 2322 cm−1) were not detected over Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts. Meanwhile, there existed distinct peaks at 1529, 1556, 1599 and 1441 cm−1, which were assigned to the adsorbed acetamide anion (CH3CONHad) [55–57]. As reported [55,56], the carbon of CN group would be nucleophilically attacked by surface OH groups to form CH3CONHad. Thus, it was deduced that CH3CN molecules could easily transform into CH3CONHad after adsorbing on the surface of the two catalysts. Furthermore, the bands assigned to CH3CONHad could be always observed until up to high temperature, indicating this was a crucial intermediate product during CH3CN degradation process. More importantly, the bands attributed to CH3CONH2 (at 1664, 1661 and 1585 cm−1), CH3COOH (at 1483, 1480 and 1359 cm−1) and NH x species (at 3363, 3276, 3178 cm−1) could be observed at 100 °C. And it could be found that these bands initially increased with elevating temperature, then vanished gradually at 250 °C. By contrast, the bands of NCO species appeared at the medium temperature (200 °C) and became intense with temperature further rising. These results indicated transformation of CH3CN, through CH3CONHad and CH3CONH2, to form NH3 and CH3COOH was the main process at low temperature. However, in high temperature range, the N-containing species were mainly converted into NCO species, which would be further oxidized into NO x and CO2. It was worth noting that the peak intensity of NCO species continued to increase in the high-temperature region, whereas the peaks belonged to CH3CONHad became weak in the identical temperature range. Combined the presence of CH3 species (at 2999, 2933 and 2851 cm−1) [15], it could be assumed that NCO species was formed by cleavage of the C–C bond and dehydrogenation of CH3CONHad. Additionally, the appearance temperature (100 °C) of bands assigned to CH3CONH2 on Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts was lower than that case of Cu/ZSM-5 catalyst (150 °C), indicating that hydrolysis reaction was more easily to occur on Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts with Lewis acids, which could also be verified by the result of hydrolysis measurements (Fig. S6). Moreover, there were some differences about in-situ DRIFTS between the Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts. Different from Cu/TiO2 catalyst, the extra characteristic bands of 2236 cm−1 could be observed on Cu/Al2O3 catalyst, which was attributed to N2O [58]. The appearance of N2O was not too hard to understand because it had worse reducibility than Cu/TiO2 catalyst. This phenomenon was accordance with the NO x and N2O yield (Fig. 1d and Fig. S1b) in the activity test results. Additionally, the appearance temperature regarding CO vibration peak (at 2006 and 2145 cm–1) [59] and bidentate carbonates vibration peak (at 1346 cm–1) [60] over Cu/Al2O3 catalyst were all increased from 150° to 200°C compared to Cu/TiO2 catalyst, manifesting the carbon-containing intermediate products on Cu/Al2O3 catalyst were more difficult to be oxidized. This was also due to its relatively poor reducibility on Cu/Al2O3 catalyst. 3.5 Discussion Based on the analysis above, it was concluded that the acidity of the catalysts played very important roles in N-containing products formation and reaction pathway during CH3CN catalytic degradation process. And the mechanism of the reaction over the Cu-based catalysts with different supports was shown in Fig. 8. On the Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts surface (Fig. 8a), CH3CN was easily converted into CH3CONHad with the involvement of OH groups. Then, the further degradation pathway of CH3CONHad was strongly associated with reaction temperature. In low temperature region, the reaction mainly followed hydrolysis mechanism. Specifically, CH3CONHad would further be hydrogenated to generate CH3CONH2 species, which further reacted with H2O to yield NH3 and CH3COOH. However, oxidation pathway was the dominant process within high temperature range. During this oxidation process, NCO species would produce after the scission of C–C bond and dehydrogenation of CH3CONHad species. After that, N2O and NO x formed with the further oxidation of NCO species. And the mechanism of the CH3CN oxidation over the Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts can be described by the following equations: Initial hydrolysis step: (1) H2O +Ov → -OH (2) CH3CN + -OH → -CH3CONH + Ov Hydrolysis pathway (at low temperatures): (3) -CH3CONH + -OH → CH3CONH2 +-O (4) CH3CONH2 + H2O → NH3 + CH3COOH (5) CH3COOH + -O → CO2 + H2O Oxidation pathway (at high temperatures): (6) -CH3CONH + -OH→ -CH3 + -NCO + H2O (7) -NCO + -O → N2 or NO x + CO2 (8) -CH3 + -O→ CO2 + H2O For Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts (Fig. 8b), hydrolysis and oxidation pathways of CH3CN occurred simultaneously. On the one hand, the CN group of CH3CN could react with H2O to generate CH3CONH2, which would continue to be hydrolyzed to form NH3 and CH3COOH. On the other hand, the C–C bond rupture of CH3CN could take place and CN group would be direct oxidized to –NCO species, which could be further oxidized to generate NO x . The direct oxidation pathway of CH3CN mainly happened on CuO species of these two samples, since the mainly oxidation pathway was observed on Cu/S-1 catalyst. Owing to the strong Brønsted acid sites of Cu/ZSM-5 samples, abundant Cu2+ ions were generated via ion-exchange effect, which were very active in SCR reaction between NH3 and NO x . As such, though the CH3CN hydrolysis on ZSM-5 support was not reactive compared to TiO2/Al2O3 support due to the inhibition effect of strong NH3 adsorption on ZSM-5 support [19], the NO x generation derived from CH3CN oxidation pathway on CuO in Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts could promote the proceed of hydrolysis reaction via an iSCR reaction on Cu2+ ions. This would lead to the effective occurrence of the two reaction pathways in parallel, exhibiting well N2 selectivity. The reaction steps of the CH3CN oxidation over the Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts can be described by the following equations: Hydrolysis pathway: (9) CH3CN + H2O → CH3CONH2 (10) CH3CONH2 + H2O → NH3 + CH3COOH Oxidation pathway: (11) CH3CN → -CH3 + -CN (12) -CN + -O → -NCO (13) -NCO + -O →N2 or NO x + CO2 (14) CH3COOH + -O → CO2 + H2O Internal SCR reaction: (15) NH3 + NO x + -O → N2 + H2O 4 Conclusions In this study, a series of Cu-based catalysts with different supports (TiO2, Al2O3, ZSM-5(27), ZSM-5(85) and S-1) were prepared, and the catalytic degradation performance of CH3CN were investigated. It was found that Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited superior CH3CN conversion but poor N2 selectivity. For instance, Cu/TiO2 catalyst showed an over 90 % CH3CN conversion from 275 °C, while its N2 selectivity was lower than 70 % at 275–500 °C with massive NH3 generation at low temperature and NO x formation at higher temperatures. In comparison, Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts possessed better N2 selectivity, where Cu/ZSM-5(27) catalyst exhibited more than 95 % N2 selectivity and CH3CN conversion at 350–500 °C. The acidity of the catalysts played an important role in CH3CN degradation pathway. On Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts mainly with Lewis acid sites, CH3CN would react rapidly with surface hydroxy group to form acetamide anion (CH3CONHad), and the next reaction pathway was closely related to the reaction temperature. At low temperatures, CH3CONHad would be hydrogenated to generate CH3CONH2 species, which was followed by the further hydrolysis reaction to form NH3. At high temperatures, CH3CONHad was preferred to undergo oxidation reaction pathway, producing a large amount of NO x . However, for Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts with Brønsted acid sites, both hydrolysis and oxidation pathways of CH3CN proceeded simultaneously, which was derived from the adequate occurrence of iSCR reaction on the abundant isolated Cu2+ ions. And the coordination of hydrolysis and oxidation pathways was benefit to the improvement of N2 selectivity. Additionally, the CH3CN degradation on Cu/S-1 catalyst mainly followed the oxidation mechanism due to its less acidity. These findings unveiled the influence of acidic types in reaction mechanism and offered precious insights for the development of high-performance NVOCs catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A series of Cu-based catalysts with different types of supports (TiO2, Al2O3, S-1, HZSM-5 SiO2/Al2O3 =27 and 85) were investigated for selective catalytic combustion of acetonitrile (CH3CN). Among all catalysts, the Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts had superior activity accompanied with the generation of massive NO x , while Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts exhibited excellent N2 selectivity. The characterization results indicated that the surface acidity of catalysts played a decisive role in reaction behavior. For the Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts mainly with Lewis acid sites, CH3CN underwent an initial hydrolysis step with surface hydroxy group to form acetamide anion (CH3CONHad), then occurred further hydrolysis reaction to form NH3 at low temperatures, or turned to proceed oxidation reaction with numerous NO x generation at high temperatures. Whereas, the enriched Brønsted acid sites on the Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts brought abundant isolated Cu2+ ions, which guaranteed the processing of iSCR reaction, thereby promoting the occurrence of hydrolysis and oxidation reaction pathways in parallel and benefiting the improvement of N2 selectivity. These results elucidated the influence of supports with different acidic types in reaction pathway and provided precious reference for the development of high-performance NVOCs catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic insight into reaction behaviors of acetonitrile catalytic combustion over Cu-based catalysts with different supports
